addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall secretary to her Ma
tie
.

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 July 9
9 July 1589
It may please yo
r
H. the 2 of this moneth
I re
c
yo
r
H. of
e 23 of June, w
t
two
from her
Ma
tie
and all
e other writinges spe-
cified in yo
r
letter, and by
e
Lordes
of the
councell: as likewise yo
r
last of
e 26 of
June, but this bearer
M
r
Charles
.
I have cause to mervell at
at w
ch
yo
r
H. doth
write of
e insolent speeches of
e Deputies.
For two of them are accounted of
e discretest
of this councell: and I have seldome in this
place seen them overpassionat. But they take
e same course, as
e rest in this place. In
privat c
o
munication, both one w
t
an other, and
w
t
me, they will all of them, as those Deputies
have done if often, condemne
e presumption
of those,
at have caused this badde correspon-
dence between her Ma
tie
and
e contrey: and
yet they dare not publickly use any opposition:
lest it falle out w
t
them, as w
t
others
at are in
prison in these contreis, and those captaines in
England, and els where, that live in b
a
nishm
t
and povertie. Uppon
at w
ch
yo
r
H doth
desire to have deciphred, as touching
e occasion
of
e stoute kinde of cariage, wherto
e
states
are lately growen,
M
r
Gilpin
and I have
debated sundrie times, and have used as vigi-
lant eies as was possible to observe all their
hopes and dessignes. But we can not per-
ceave that their affiance is in France: or
that they make any suche reckning, as if they
could c
o
clude their owne peace w
t
e Spaniard:
as doutles there are but fewe among them
that imagine,
at w
t
out her Ma
ties
assistance
ei
can stand of themselves. But to signifie di-
rectly w
at
I thinke, They conceave their in-
terest in this publicke cause to be no greater then her Ma
ties
fol.10v
whatsoever demonstrations have bin made to
e con-
trary, and howsoever it hath pleased her Hig
nes
by
sundrie both letters and messages, to menace to for-
sake them for their ungratefulnes, it is heere very
easie to be seene,
at they make but smale account
of suche kind
of persuasions. And thought they doe
not openly declare it, yet it is well knowen, that
among themselves they doe it, and will shewe it more
and more, as occasions are presented, by their ma-
ner of proceeding. In
e cause of
vas-
seur
,
Nota
This Vasseur a dutchem
a
was a
servant to
S
r
William Russel
and a
prisoner for sinister dealings
betwixt Russel and the Estates
afterward delivred.
they have bin silent sins my last to yo
r
H.
I have claimed him in suche sort and forme, as yo
w
may see by
e inclosed. That advise w
ch
yo
r
H
sent me in Frenche, would by no meanes serve
e
turne,
e first point excepted. For where it is
argued,
at the states are a partie, and can be
no judges, it is impertinent to
at course w
ch
is held
for
at
e mater is judicially handled by none but
e
councell of state
, who are an other assemblie, and
an inferiour court to
e Generall states. The
other reasons there alleaged do so extenuat his
fact, as if her Ma
tie
had absolved him already
whiche if I should deliver in
at order, I knowe
it would occasion a great discontenm
t
. The
consideration of these reasons w
ch
I proposed, was
c
o
mitted to certain Doctors of
e councell, whose
decision was, that
ei were not sufficient to exempt
e prisoner from
e Contrey. Their allegations
against them, I req
e
sted to have delivered unto
me, wherto I thinke they will yelde, and I will
send them to yo
r
H. As I have signified to
S
r
William Russel, two or three wordes from the
Deputies in
England,
in
e favo
r
of
e partie, or els
from himself, as taking his farewell of
e contrey,
would doe a great deale of good. In
e mean while,
I doe thinke there is so muche done in his behalf, a
[s]
they will nether putt him to
e torture, nor take
away his life: and w
at
I maye doe further, shalbe
fol.11r
diligently perfourmed. Sins
e sealing of
my letter to
e Lordes, I am certified, that the Ge-
nerall states have sent
e copie of her Ma
ties
l
re
,
my proposition, and
e Articles, to all
e Provinces,
w
ch
I trust will returne their Answear with speede. The Ennemie hath come
of late before
Utrecht,
and caried away 500 head
of cattle: whiche caused for
e time some tumult
in
e towne: but all is well appeared.
S
r
Martin Schincke
hath victualed
Berke
w
t
a
monethes victualls, and doth intend, uppon order
from hens, to put in more. The
taking of those sconces, of w
ch
I writte in my last,
in
e quarters of
Groeninghen,
hath putt
Verdugo
in suche feare, as he will nether enter into Groe-
ninghen towne, nor into
Delfsiel,
but keepeth
among
e villages: whiche doth putt us in good
hope, that there will be in
e end a generall re-
volt. The Generall states have licen-
sed S
r
Martin Schincke to take
e towne of
Rees,
or
any other place of
e
D. of Cleves
, that may make
for his advantage.
M
r
Gilpin
will
make petition to yo
r
H. to gette some order for
his pay. I knowe yo
r
H. affection unto him, and
in that respect, I knowe my sute in his behalf will
be altogether needeles. Nevertheles because I see him
often disapointed, and sometimes trobled in his
buisnes, for want of his mony, I am to beseeche
yo
r
H. w
t
him,
at he may have some suche warrant, as
e
Treasurer at warres
may accept
it once for all.
And so I take my humble leave
From
e Hage July 9. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
If her Ma
tie
be resolved to continew her
challenge of Vasseur, it will be requisit that my
Lordes of
e Councell should make answear to
at
Letter w
ch
was sent unto them from this Councell of
state, and require them to proceede no further, till
e case be decided by
e consultation of learned
men on bothe sides, to the end
e like question may
not troble them hereafter.
